newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel targets labour office for savings - report.
newsitem.headline: Waigel targets labour office for savings - report.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel is planning to reduce the nation's budget deficit by slashing funding for the Federal Labour Office, a German news magazine reported on Saturday.

According to Der Spiegel magazine, Waigel wants to reduce funding to the labour office by over two billion marks during the second half of this year, reducing money for training and job creation schemes.
Spiegel released a copy of the report to the media in advance of the magazine's publication on Monday.

The Finance Minister, fighting to reduce government red ink in a bid to qualify for European economic and monetary union (EMU), is also targeting Christmas bonuses for government employees as another way to save money, the magazine said.
The report of Waigel's plans comes only a day after the labour office reported German unemployment rose 56,000 to a seasonally adjusted 4.358 million in May.
Bundesbank chief economist called the jobs data "more than disappointing" and said the economy was not growing fast enough to create jobs.
